title: Green Day Just Called Out Trump After the President Refused to Attend the Super Bowl & Called Them a ‚ÄòTerrible Choice‚Äô
description: Likely thing for them to do!
fullText:
Green Day has never been part of the MAGA agenda. The California rock band has called out Donald Trump and his administration in many of their music performances, and it doesn‚Äôt look like they‚Äôre stopping any time soon.

In recent years, the band‚Äîconsisting of members Billie Joe Armstrong, Mike Dirnt, and Tr√© Cool‚Äîhas replaced the lyrics of their iconic hit ‚ÄúAmerican Idiot.‚Äù The song, written in 2004, initially included the lyrics¬†‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a part of a redneck agenda.‚Äù Now, when performing the song live, Armstrong sings, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not part of the MAGA agenda.‚Äù The song itself, and the titular album it was written for, was a direct criticism of George W. Bush‚Äôs administration and the Iraq war.

Trump Finally Addresses Savannah Guthrie's Mom's Abduction Years After She Called His Behavior 'Crazy' at Town Hall

White House Officially Addresses Trump & Vance Feud Rumors After Reports the President Is Prepared to 'Strike' Against the VP's 'Betrayal'

Armstrong also takes a jab at Vice President JD Vance through revised lyrics of ‚ÄúJesus of Suburbia.‚Äù So what‚Äôs the beef between the president and the band?

After Donald Trump was elected into office in November 2016, the band led a chant ¬†‚ÄúNo Trump, no KKK, no fascist USA‚Äù¬†during an appearance at the¬†American Music Awards.

During the first days of the first Trump administration, Billie Joe Armstrong wrote on Instagram about his immigration executive orders that targeted countries with large Muslim populations: ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm in a state of shock. The executive orders Trump is signing feels like a vendetta.. Trump is not only taking out his revenge on the people who protested him, but also the average American that just didn‚Äôt vote for him.‚Äù

He continued, ‚ÄúThese reckless decisions on healthcare, muslim-americans, immigration, environmental protection, freedom of speech, freedom of press, women‚Äôs right to choose what to do with their bodies, suggesting sending in the feds to Chicago .. are signs of a man that is trying to redefine what it is that keeps our common union as Americans. This is not just his ‚Äòconservative agenda.‚Äô¬†It‚Äôs an all out assault on our civil liberties. His intention is to divide us as Americans.¬†Maybe we don‚Äôt agree on all of these issues.. But can‚Äôt we see eye to eye on some?‚Äù

In an interview with NME, Armstrong said that Trump supporters were mostly¬†‚Äúuneducated white working-class people.‚Äù Armstrong¬†added: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem right there. There‚Äôs this white nationalism that‚Äôs been brewing under the radar for a long time. But now [Trump‚Äôs] been able to cause people to lash out and blame minorities and it‚Äôs really confusing. I mean, blatant misogyny going on at the same time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got family members from Oklahoma that are big Trump supporters. And there‚Äôs no clear answer on why they‚Äôre supporting him because he doesn‚Äôt even have any policies,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúHow can you have an opinion about who you want for the Leader of the Free World when the guy running doesn‚Äôt have answers to any questions?‚Äù

When the band performed in Washington D.C., Armstrong emphasized that the sentiments didn‚Äôt feel as intense or different as other concerts. ‚ÄúOutside of ‚Äúf‚Äîk you,‚Äù not a real lot, honestly,‚Äù the lead singer told Rolling Stone. ‚ÄúPeople know how I feel. I feel like going negative is just throwing fuel on the fire. I feel like the government is trying to create a culture war between us in a lot of ways. They‚Äôre trying to get between your average citizens based on red and blue. I think we‚Äôre in a crisis mode right now. For me, it‚Äôs important to get back to fundamentally what it feels like to be an American. We all come from different backgrounds, but we come together and create this world. It‚Äôs like a microcosm for the rest of the world. I want people to feel unity when they come to a show. At the same time, I‚Äôm not going to puss out on saying what I feel about him and his administration.‚Äù

When asked about their obligations in the Trump administration, Cool said, ‚ÄúI think we have an obligation to put on a fun show and put on a concert that‚Äôs memorable, that‚Äôs energetic and that spreads joy and open-mindedness. If being open-minded and joyful is against your political beliefs, then you know, fuck you.‚Äù

In June 2025, Armstrong shared his feelings about the president. ‚ÄúDonald Trump in his administration¬†is a fascist government,‚Äù Armstrong told the crowd at Download Festival in Donington Park in the U.K.¬†. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs up to us to fight back.‚Äù

Green Day was announced as a performer in the opening ceremonies for Super Bowl LX at Levi‚Äôs Stadium, Santa Clara, Calif., a couple of miles away from the band‚Äôs roots. When asked about whether he‚Äôll attend the football game, Trump told reporters that he would not and then criticized the performers, which also included halftime performer Bad Bunny. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm anti-them. I think it‚Äôs a terrible choice. All it does is sow hatred. Terrible,‚Äù Trump said.

In their first performance of 2026, the band made their stance loud and clear with the iconic ‚ÄúAmerican Idiot‚Äù line. During the performance of ‚ÄúHoliday‚Äù and ‚ÄúKnow Your Enemy,‚Äù Armstrong said, ‚ÄúThis song is anti-fascism. This song is anti-war. We stand up for our brothers and sisters in Minnesota. ‚Ä¶ Ladies and gentlemen, Stephen Miller now has the floor,‚Äù referring to the ICE raids in Minneapolis that resulted in the deaths of Alex Pretto and Renee Good, while the latter line is a direct reference to homeland security advisor Stephen Miller.

Armstrong also added the same sentiments when the band performed at a Super Bowl pre-show hosted by Spotify and Fanduel on Friday, Feb. 6. ‚ÄúThis goes out to all the ICE agents out there. Wherever you are: quit your shitty-ass job. Quit that shitty job you have.‚Äù He added, ‚Äúcome on this side of the line.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause when this is over ‚Äî and it will be over at some point in time ‚Äî Kristi Noem, Stephen Miller, J.D. Vance,¬†Donald Trump, they‚Äôre going to drop you like a bad f‚Äîking habit.‚Äù
